title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not identify one factor that contributes to high crude death rates in countries that have never experienced the changes that result from a demographic transition, such as any of the following:

· Unsafe drinking water/lack of access to clean drinking water

· Loss of agricultural land for crops and livestock

· Lack of access to health care

· High rates of diseases such as heart disease, respiratory infections, HIV/AIDS, malaria, tuberculosis

· High infant mortality

· Risk of death during pregnancy (from lack of quality health care)

title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe a typical age structure diagram for a developing country, such as any of the following:

· A rapidly growing population will have a higher proportion of younger people than will a stable or declining population.

· A rapidly growing population will have more individuals in younger cohorts/prereproductive stage than individuals in older cohorts/reproductive and postreproductive stage.

· A developing country often has a pyramid-shaped age structure diagram, with more individuals in younger cohorts at the broad base.

title: Part D(ii)
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not make a claim to propose a solution that would reduce the amount of water required to produce enough food for individuals, such as any of the following:

· Eat lower on the food chain/reduce consumption of animal protein.

· Produce plant-based sources of protein.

· Implement efficient irrigation for growing crops.

· Plant local crops that do not require as much water.

· Plant genetically modified crops that do not require much water.

· Discourage the production of beef in favor of production of less water-intensive livestock such as chicken.

· Discourage the use of feedlots, which can lead to soil compaction and increase runoff.

title: Part D(iii)
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe one environmental disadvantage, other than problems associated with consumption of water, such as any of the following:

· More land is required to produce the same number of calories from meat as from plants.

· Use of animal feedlots to raise animals generates large amounts of organic waste, which can contaminate ground and surface waters.

· Use of animal feedlots to raise animals increases the incidence of disease in livestock, has an unpleasant odor, and/or increases water pollution.

· Overgrazing can occur when too many animals feed on a particular area of land, which can increase soil erosion.

· Overgrazing can occur when too many animals feed on a particular area of land, which can lead to desertification.

· Cattle release greenhouse gases such as methane, which can exacerbate global climate change.
